threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

threads.sub: Replacing my 12v car battery with 18650s without a BMS
threads.com:
We all know charging 18650s above 4.2v is bad.

Lets say my car alternator charges the lead acid battery to 14v.

If I parallel 4 x 18650 at 4.2v the maximum safe voltage would be 16.8v. This is above the max voltage the alternator outputs, which is 14v.

So at 14v each 18650 cell would be at only 3.5v, and I don't have to worry about overcharging since once the 18650s are at 14v they simply won't accept any more current since the voltage isn't rising.

Now if I add multiple parallel banks of 4 x 18650s I would have each cell at 3.5v but lot of available current, enough to start a car.

So doing it this way, I figure I don't need a BMS since there is no way the 18650s can be overcharged. Tell me if I am wrong?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502691
each 18650 has a max discharge current of about 20a so you would have to parallel 5 to 10 cells to get 100 to 200a, then series those in 3 packs for the 12.6v.

18650's are a terrible idea for a car battery.

https://insideevs.com/news/587455/batteries-tesla-using-electric-cars/#:~:text=Tesla%20simply%20decided%20to%20use,quality%20and%20in%20high%20volume.

When the company started its journey with the original Tesla Roadster, there were not many types of lithium-ion batteries to choose from. Tesla simply decided to use 18650-type (recently called 1865) cylindrical batteries, designed for general purpose (slightly adapted to EVs).

They were difficult to use, due to a high number of small cells (low capacity) in the battery pack (several thousand), but available at a consistent quality and in high volume. With outstanding engineering to handle electrical and thermal management (liquid cooling), Tesla went the pragmatic path (some other companies started to use the new pouch or prismatic cell types at the time).

divide top portion into two right triangles
base is 8 ft so other side should be 8 ft since its angles are 45-45-90. Pythagorean theorem --> 8^2 + 8^2 = x^2 ---> x = sqrt (8^2+8^2) = sqrt(128) which is around 11.315 ft, or 135.78 inches, rounding to nearest quarter inch gives 135.75 inches which is within the realm of "close enough".
alternatively cos (pi/4) = 8/x --> x=8/cos(pi/4) = 8/(1/sqrt(2)) = 8 * sqrt(2)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503538
So the only two drawbacks are longer and heavier?

The benefits are way more powerful (they have tons of torque to cut through practically anything), longevity (I personally have burned up many shitty top handle circular saws and even a hypoid saw, but I have never yet killed a worm drive saw although I'm giving it my best try), AND if you ever do have any issues there are parts available for them as they have essentially remained unchanged for ages. There's a reason they're regarded as the best circular saws out there for demanding applications.

So what benefits are there of top handle saws? Lighter? Weaker? Less torque? More prone to dying on you? Sounds amazing!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503623
>tons of torque to cut through practically anything
Never really had this problem with my standard saw, if you use good blades you can cut through things just fine.
>there are parts available for them
I can get replacements for most parts on my saw that could break. Being able to buy replacement parts is not a feature exclusive to a worm drive saws, it's a feature common to tools made by an actually decent manufacturer.
>longevity
Not an issue. I've been using the same saw for probably coming up on 15 years now. If your tool has no longevity it's either because you don't take care of it, or because it's shitty pro-sumer grade junk. Yet another thing that has nothing to do with whether or not it's a worm drive saw.

You're not describing the benefits of a worm drive saw, you're describing the benefits of a well built tool. My standard circular saw has all of the benefits you mentioned, without the drawbacks that I mentioned. So to restate what I already said, I would see no benefit from switching from a standard circular saw to a worm drive saw aside from having a little more precision in long straight cuts, which is something that becomes a non-issue with experience and skill. If I were to switch the only difference it would make is that the saw I'm using would be heavier and less maneuverable, neither of which are traits that I look for in the tools I use.

>>2502932
>but it won't stop fermenting
Is it really fermenting or is it just releasing all the CO2 that was previously solved in solution?
You can rack it into a large pot and with a large spoon stir it gently to get the CO2 out (at least 5 minutes), then rack it into your jug again.
If you're taking gravity readings you can check if it's really fermenting. In the past 10 years I had a handful of batches fail, one of them I remember because it was the first and up til now only bacterial infection I got. It was foamlessly bubbling for weeks in a manner like the surface of a freshly poured glass of mineral water looks. Gravity never changed and the batch continued to bubble for 3 weeks until the gas leaving the airlock started to smell stale and musty and suddenly the flavor turned just abysmally bad. A wine cooper friend of mine then diagnosed the bacterial infection from my description.

last_replies.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
last_replies.com:
>>2503511
What will be the main thing you'll brew with it?
A lot of people make a fetish out of temperature control, in my opinion that's only necessary in specialty beers (e.g. Saison) and if you have not a single place on hand with a stable temperature environment.
If you have a cellar or basement with a constant temperature in the operating range of your yeast, you won't need temperature control on your fermenter.
In the end it's a nice to have but not something I'd waste 600 bucks for.
Just as a comparison, the 30 liter stainless steel fermenter from Brew Monk has a port for temperature probe (Probe with digital thermometer pre-installed), only costs 199.95€ and you can even get a chiller for that fermenter for 89.95€.
Those of course don't offer the functionality of being a keg and a fermenter in one, but for the money you saved, you can get 3 normal kegs on top.

Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502001
more tips

get a cheap vacuum cleaner to suck off dust while cutting plates. NEVER CUT OR GRIND EPOXY THAT'S NOT FULLY CURED! Highly cancerous. I always let each plate dry for 2 days atleast before continuing work on it. Don't use your household cleaner, the filters will clog with fine dust and it gives off an aweful smell, I found a working Samsung vacuum cleaner on the sidewalk, perfect for the job.

Wear gloves, eyeprotection and a mask, put on maybe 3 or so one use gloves on each hand, this way you can pull one off if too much wet epoxy is on it and continue to work on your piece.

A good measurement for epoxy I found out for my project is, a 33cm x 33cm sized plate consisiting of 9 light + 9 heavy glass cloth requires aproximatily 750g of epoxy. Epoxy resin is mixed with it's hardener usually in a ratio 2:1, two parts resin one part hardener. For 750g total it's 500g resin + 250g hardener. Weight and volume is almost the same, one kg is one litre. All my pieces cured fine and I never measured 100% perfect. Keep track of how much epoxy you used up on your first piece, then you can calculate it better the next time.

That's what I can think of currenty. Ask me more if you want.

>room rumble
WTF is room rumble?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503473
low frequency rumble caused by mechanical vibrations of the structure, common causes are things like traffic on nearby roads or water running through a pipe. This is why recording studios often build a room inside a room that is isolated from the structure on all 6 sides. For the home studio you generally can just get away with filtering and gain staging to get rid of it/cover it up.

I could outdo a chain saw when it comes to squaring up some pine logs, go down the log doing the relief cut, then go back knocking off the waste, roll the log, repeat. Each side takes slightly long then it takes to walk the length of the log, two wacks for each relief cut and one for removing the waste. With two people you can really move through a lot of pine. My first job was peeling logs, my second job was squaring them, only used the power tools for joinery and cross cutting.

With a chainsaw you have to go slow when doing such things or you make more work for yourself afterwards because the cut is to jagged for the joinery work. Chainsaws are a fair amount of work, the muscles you use are used in a way most people never will use those muscles so they spend a day fighting with a chain saw and they be beat by the end of the day and will hurt the next day. Now if I had to buck a good sized pine into lengths suitable for a fireplace then the chainsaw will win out but with the right saw you can really move through pine and it is a hell of a lot more enjoyable than listening to the saw and breathing the exhaust. But when you got that fallen oak to cut up then breathing that exhaust does not seem so bad.

You can use most any axe, but the broad axe is the one designed for the task and is easier/less work since it has enough weight to just let it do all the work when dealing with a wood like pine and it being flat on one side means you can get a quite flat and even face without much work, at least you can once you get good at making all your relief cuts the same depth.

Squaring it up will make it easier to pull up hill if you are using rollers, but if you are not it just gives you a couple sharp edges that are good at digging in. Best way to go is to wait until winter and the ground freezes but before much snow accumulates. But if you must deal with soft ground then it is best to go over the ground instead of on the ground. Get a copy of Moving Heavy Things by Jan Adkins, should help you figure out a way to move it without much fuss. FM 5 34 (army engineer field data) is also helpful to have about but it is written for field engineers or the like so it can send you chasing your tail if you do not know exactly what you are looking for and what you need. Most if not all of the time Moving Heavy Things should cover you and you would be wise to always start there before touching FM 5 34.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503248
That's called level winding (or is a type of level winding*) and is done with a winder (aka a "spooler") with a guide that moves across the open face of the spool or bobbin as it rotates...it's a fairly common feature in some styles of fishing reels and cable winches and you can get them for yarn making and winding bobbins for things like weaving-
https://hansencrafts.com/cherry-woolee-winder/
https://myautowinder.com/
Simple ones loke in fishing reels use a direct gear drive to move the guide as the main axle spins, really sophisticated ones for manufacturing have sensors that adjust the guide motion and other factors as the material diameter increases, which is how the ones like your pic are so perfect-

"In spooling or level-wind applications, material is wound onto a spool. As the material's diameter changes on the supply spool, and on the the take-up spool, it’s critical to maintain the proper speed of each spool. Encoders provide the motion feedback to help maintain that speed.

Encoder feedback also helps monitor the length of material and helps maintain the proper tension on the material to avoid stretching, breaking or winding too tightly or loosely. "

https://www.encoder.com/spooling-level-wind

*specifically it's "cross wound" and here's a whole thing on why that might be done-

https://archaicarcane.com/standing-at-a-crossroads-thread-cross-wound-vs-stack-wound/comment-page-1/

>>2503146
>You are utterly full of shit, parroting the nonsensical "tonewood" bullshit.
Agreed and the entire heavy/dense = better thing and the "sympathetic resonance kills sustain" argument is pulled from the deepest recesses of his ass too.
Fact is that woods used in instruments are often chosen for structural and wear and stability and working qualities far more than for subtle nuance of tone, and where they are used to affect tonal and other qualities like sustain, crisp attack, etc. they are often used in combinations of "better" more exotic species and "lesser" quality woods to fine tune resonance and other qualities in certain frequency ranges.
Cedar is very soft and not dense and is used all the time in acoustics for guitars used in music that favors its sonic qualities, like classical guitar.
Some highly prized woods like mahogany sound like shit if you build an entire guitar out of them, and need a super stiff dense wood like a maple or ebony fingerboard or body cap to give it any attack and brightness at all.
Conversely an all hard maple guitar will be all bite and attack and treble with minimal depth and warmth.

tl;dr: sustain isn't everything and there is such a thing as too much of any "good" sonic quality in a guitar; balance is what matters...but only if the thing is structurally sound and stable, which matters most.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I've built an electric kit, generic inexpensive tele style. The only woodworking I had to do with it was shape the headstock blank. Did alright but I got some splintering, probably because I went yolo with a tenon saw - I'm not much of a carpenter - but enough sanding solved the worst of the damage. For me most of the work went into the paintjob, in that I wanted to get a really good solid finish, which I achieved to my satisfaction, over months of spraying, drying, sanding, spraying, drying, sanding, etc.

The rest of the build was just bolt the parts together, so nothing complicated. Finished the neck with Danish oil, had to get a set of files to adjust the nut, try and get the whole thing set up nice. It's not a great player, or else I'd look to invest in better electronics than the cheapo stuff that came with the kit, but it's fine. Reckon it'll make a nephew a nice first guitar Christmas present or something.

I'm sure I could probably spend some more time working on the set-up to try and get a better action out of it - what's nice with a cheap kit is that I'm not at all concerned with giving the truss-rod a good crank to see what happens; if it snaps the neck I can just replace it, or even take my first foray into repair.

Reckon my next project would be along the lines of doing a strip and respray. I've got an old genero-caster hanging around that plays well but the electrics are shot, might make the perfect victim.

its not a mop made entirely out of steam, retard, steam mops have an absorbent fiber pad that you take off and wash.
You dont have to wring them out because they barely use any water, unless you're dumb enough to try to use one to soak up a large liquid spill...in the rare event that you need to do that kind of mopping up you can just use an old towel or a big sponge or paper towels and clean off any residue if needed with the steam mop.

They aren't intended to replace all other mops for any purpose and the good ones do a lot more than just floors. They also minimize the need for cleaners and sanitize far better than traditional mops can, and don't slop water around that can promote mold and mildew under baseboards and in other crevices.
When and where they make sense like with tile and brick surfaces and tight areas around fixtures like toilets they're great and not having to deal with buckets and dumping dirty water is awesome. Plus you can use attachments to do things like clean car wheels and take wrinkles out of clothing and drapes, and remove wallpaper and even steam wood for bending.

>>2503061
Don’t trust a 3/8” for lug nuts. The torque specs are all just numbers, and a lot of 1/2” guns in the 300ft-lb rated range won’t budge lug nuts that weren’t freshly torqued to spec in the past month won’t consistently remove lug nuts.

Honestly for automotive, the newest gen of brushless 1/2” mid-torques are great. They’re about the size of a drill and will crack loose 95% of nuts and bolts on cars unless it’s a total rustbucket. Check the model #s too because I know the DeWalt mid torque jumped in power a lot with no aesthetic change and you will be leaving a lot on the table if you jump on the older model to save $50.

Also the compact 3/8” guns are way down the priority list for DIYers, they don’t have much more power than a 1/4” driver with a socket adapter and you won’t have the power to do the jobs that are a pain with hand tools. Don’t be a cheap ass and buy an old 3/8” that is basically a backup impact driver.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2499809
If you are just using screws for the clamping action you can make pilot holes in the top piece that are just large enough that the screw threads can't bite into them, and then depending on the material and screw, a normal sized or no pilot hole in the bottom part for maximum bite. Then when the screw goes in the head clamps the top part tight.
The mistake noobs make is to let the screw threads bite into the top piece and then when it hits to bottom piece it acts like a screw jack to separate them before biting in...since the threads in the top piece prevent it from sliding that gap can't close up on its own.

To clarify, it's not the breaker itself that trips, but the main breaker overall that trips while the lights breaker is on. I tried turning each individual breaker off before turning back on the tripped breaker to find the culprit. While the lights breaker is off, everything else is fine.
The odd thing is that the amount of time that the main breaker trips varies. Sometimes it won't want to turn back on at all, sometimes it will trip instantly, sometimes it will trip after a second or two.

How do I go about diagnosing and finding the problem? Do I turn off each switch one by one until I find the culprit? What possible reasons are there for a lights breaker for tripping other than a short?

Pic related for UK and non-UKfags - this isn't my breaker box, but it's identical. The one highlighted in red is like the semi-main breaker; that's the one that's tripping. One of the breakers highlighted in yellow would be my ground floor lights breaker - if that's turned off, then the breaker in red doesn't trip anymore. In the UK, it's normally one of the individual breakers that trip rather than the semi-main one, which is why this is unusual.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502942
this isn't going to be helpful to you op but i just feel like sharing anyway, i had a similar issue where three or four times the rcd tripped when someone turned a light on or off, problem was i wasn't around when it happened and the stories changed, maybe it was this switch, maybe it was a different light, can't quite remember.
well i wasn't keen to rip out half of the house to find a frayed wire so some narrowing down was required.
so anyway about 100 quid later i'm folded up under the stairs pulling out the rcd and swapping the mcbs for rcbos, simple enough to narrow it down for sure that way.
turns out it was the oven, oven elements are apparently notorious for absorbing moisture and cracking and shorting themselves very slowly to ground.
it tripped a couple of times and i explained what the issue was and someone managed to put together that turning the top half of the oven on or off didn't trip, but as it heated up or cooled down it would trip as the element expanded, but if it tripped and you reset it would keep going fine.
so anyway swapped the element over and it was all hunky dory.
the thing about rcds is that its cumulative, your lighting circuit might have a few ma leakage by whatever means when you do x,y,z and then you have something unrelated leaking a large amount all the time, and you think oh because i turned this off it stopped, that is the culprit.
well it isn't always. just be careful.
good luck!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503069
go outside, open the outdoor lights, see if they are full of water. earth fault means current is escaping from the line-neutral loop to earth. current at the line and neutral should be the same that is kirchoffs law, if its not then its leaking somewhere (potentially through a person which is bad, or in your case through something else which isn't quite as bad but very annoying.)
if you had a bad earth connector it wouldn't trip (nowhere for the current to escape) until you touch it and you get a little shock and hopefully the rcd cuts the power before your heart stops

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503043
Training dogs isn't that hard if you know some basic principles and avoid counterproductive methods. People who do classes tend to expect them to magically work without any extra effort; the key to any dog training being effective and sticking is to spend the right amount of time working with them, and at the right time in their development.
How much time they need to get commands or remember them, or how long a session they will tolerate before losing interest or becoming defiant just for fun depends a lot on the breed, which is another reason one size fits all classes may have limited value on their own.
But assuming you don't start too early with advanced stuff or wait until bad habits have to be unlearned, just spending the time and running through and building on basic obedience skills in a calm manner will get the typical dog used to doing what's expected of him, assuming you are *very* consistent with signals and instructions.
I mention signals first because contrary to what most people assume, using hand signals can be more effective than voice commands since dogs communicate visually. You can teach both at the same time but often when they get squirrely its the hand signal that will cut through whatever distracting them and get their attention.
They're like toddlers, and will try to interpret your voice for an angle to work and either ignore you as unserious if you try to be nice, or pout and refuse in a battle of wills if they think you aren't being nice enough.
Visual signals avoids all that and especially when more than one person will be giving commands.
But like little kids they will play any inconsistency for all they can, so you have to insist on it among the people involved, which is often more difficult than training the animal.

There are bearings in the top, and the bottom of that headset.
The spinny turny part needs held tight at the bottom, while you turn the big ring at the top that has flats like a bolt.

You unscrew it all the way and the fork comes completely out.

Clean the bearings and races out with a solvent, and then replace with real grease. any cheap NGLI2 grease from walmart.
Put it back together and itllbe good as new.

>>2500546

last_replies.name: Former Pirate Radio DJ
last_replies.com:
First off, find a frequency to operate on. If you're in a large metropolitan area, available frequencies in the FM band are going to be tough to find. Best way to do that is to drive around and tune throughout the band. Ideally, you'll want something with an open channel on both sides, but good luck.
The tricky part is determining how much power and antenna height you'll need. The simple way to figue is, if you can get an antenna about 20 - 30ft in the air, 10 watts can ideally give you a few mile radius. To double your distance, rither quadruple your power output or antenna eight.
Easiest antennas are simple 1/2 wave or 1/4 wave ground plane. You can find sites to tell you how to make those, but take a coat hanger, straighten out, and cut it to length. Use the formula 468/freq (in Mhz) then multiply by 12 to get inches for your length. Solder into a PL259 connector. Cut your radials same length and attach to the corners of the connector and bend at 45 degree angle.
20ft metal or Schedule 80 pipe works great for portable tower with a TV tripod. Use 50 ohm coax.
Transmitters can be found on E-bay. Avoid Chinese made units, for they're dirty and their singal splatters. Free Radio Berkeley still builds them by hand, but he's slow and it'll take months for him to finish.

Good luck, Anon. Read around the net to learn more. Be safe, be responsible.

They are low-tier nerds. While external control might bypass the protections against short cycling, it's not going to matter if there's any significant thermal mass (see: food) in the thing and the hysteresis of the new thermostat is reasonable (say ~2°F).

Another thing is keep it in a cool place if possible. Don't expect any economy in a sunny unventilated room.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Anyone know how to get started as a jeweler? Jewelsmith?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2501420
First thing is to get a basic understanding of the range of processes involved and how they are categorized and overlap.
It's a very broad term like "woodworking", some stuff is universal and some us very specialized.
Despite the name, lots of jewelry has nothing to do with jewels, but nearly all of it uses some degree of metalsmithing.
Even among pro jewelers many of them leave all of the actual fabriction work on the gemstones to a specialist in lapidary work.
Setting stones requires an understanding of metallurgy but may not involve any actual metal fabrication work.
Same goes for assembling jewelry from pre- made beads and other findings...you need to at least understand simple wire work.

Learning basic metalsmithing principles is the most universal foundation that lets you branch out, beginning with wire forming, them moving into cutting and soldering wire, tube and sheet material.
Casting is a whole other niche that bypasses some of that stuff but still requires understanding metal properties and basic skills to do finishing and fitting/modifications.
A hammer and anvil or at least a similar hard item/surface to beat on and some soft metal wire scraps are enough to get started learning what will/won't work and how to make that happen.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2499139
The reason why the real everdrives are so expensive is because there are special chips in many game carts and in order to run the game properly, the console needs the chip. For instance, in Super Mario RPG, they put an extra processor on board the game cartridge that works with the SNES console to run the game. The guy who made the real everdrives did all the research and found all the chips that need to be on the cartridge and got them all working on one so you can enjoy all your games on one. That guy has probably developed several years experience doing this stuff. To try and compete with that as a total newbie is silly. The knock-offs probably lack these fine details so some games probably won't work right, not only that, but the they are probably hard on your system. You're really saving yourself a huge hassle just spending the $200 on a good one.
